Introduction

The automatic nature of CMLIB means that values are parsed to be safe with the system they are going to be used with. A simple example of this is a string that is passed to a database will be escaped to make sure the value will not cause the SQL to fail.

In some cases you may want to avoid this. Using the example above a SQL include may include strings, numbers but also expressions which should not be escaped. The CMConstant class is simply a wrapper around a value of anytime. Contrary to the name the value inside the CMConstant object remains always malleable.

Usage

Creating a constant is very easy, simply send the value as a single argument to the constructor: 

 $ts = new CMConstant("some value");

Then you can pass it to a database without it escaping the value: 

 $dbh->insert('mytable', array(
   'name' => "Bob Smith",
   'secretnumber' => 34.5,
   'created' => new CMConstant("now()")
 );

Will generate and execute the SQL: 

 INSERT INTO mytable (name, secretnumber, created) VALUES ('Bob Smith', '34.5', now());

Native integration

Like all CM classes, CMConstant overrides the __toString() method so that a CMConstant value passed to any other function that doesn't understand/expect it can use it.

For example: 

 $msg = new CMConstant("Hello");
 $name = "Bob Smith";
 $greeting = "$msg $name!";      // Hello Bob Smith!
